Recall: The Laplace Transforms Procedure Given a linear PDE in u(x, t): 1 Take Laplace transforms and transform t to s. This gets rid of diﬀerentiation with respect to t and leaves an ODE involving diﬀerentiation with respect to x only (s is a parameter that is a constant as far as x is concerned). 2 We then solve the ODE (by ﬁrst year or second year methods, or even taking Laplace transforms again). 3 Arbitrary constants (which usually involve the parameter s) can be evaluated by using the given boundary conditions or by remembering that L[u(x, t)] −→ 0 as s −→ ∞. 4 Finally invert the Laplace transform. TSF - BOUNDARY VALUE PROBLEMS: FOURIER TRANSFORMS METHODSMATH2014 : MATHEMATICS II (Engineering) Question Can we use Fourier transforms to solve PDEs? A: Yes - and the method is essentially the same as in the case of Laplace transforms. Here Fourier transforms also change a PDE into an ODE. TSF - BOUNDARY VALUE PROBLEMS: FOURIER TRANSFORMS METHODSMATH2014 : MATHEMATICS II (Engineering) Some tools: We will need the following results - 1 F[f (at)] = 1 a F ( ω a ) 2 F[f ′(t)] = iωF (ω) 3 F[f ′′(t)] = −ω2F (ω) 4 F[tf (t)] = i d dω F (ω) 5 Fc[f ′(t)] = ωFs[f (t)] − √ 2 π f (0) 6 Fs[f ′(t)] = −ωFc[f (t)] 7 Fc[f ′′(t)] = −ω2Fc[f (t)] − √ 2 π f ′(0) 8 Fs[f ′′(t)] = −ω2Fs[f (t)] + √ 2 π ωf (0). TSF - BOUNDARY VALUE PROBLEMS: FOURIER TRANSFORMS METHODSMATH2014 : MATHEMATICS II (Engineering) The Fourier Transforms Procedure Given a PDE: 1 Transform the PDE using formulae for Fourier transforms above. 2 Solve the resulting ODE, using boundary conditions or properties of Fourier transforms to evaluate the arbitrary constants. 3 Use Fourier inversion to write down the solution in the form of an integral. TSF - BOUNDARY VALUE PROBLEMS: FOURIER TRANSFORMS METHODSMATH2014 : MATHEMATICS II (Engineering) Example By taking Fourier transforms with respect to x, solve the wave equation in an inﬁnite string ∂2u ∂t 2 = c 2 ∂2u ∂x 2 (−∞ < x < ∞, 0 < t < ∞) given that (i) u(x, 0) = { 1 − |x|, |x| < 1 0, |x| > 1 (ii) ∂u ∂t = 0 when t = 0, i.e., u′(x, 0) = 0. TSF - BOUNDARY VALUE PROBLEMS: FOURIER TRANSFORMS METHODSMATH2014 : MATHEMATICS II (Engineering) Solution Transform x to p, i.e., let U(p, t) = F[u(x, t)] = 1 √2π ∫ ∞ −∞ u(x, t)e −ipx dx. Then from the property F[f ′′(t)] = −ω2F (ω), we get F [∂2u ∂t 2 ] = F [ c 2 ∂2u ∂x 2 ] so that F [∂2u ∂t 2 ] = c 2(−p2U(p, t)). As in Laplace transforms, F [∂2u ∂t 2 ] = ∂2 ∂t 2 U(p, t). TSF - BOUNDARY VALUE PROBLEMS: FOURIER TRANSFORMS METHODSMATH2014 : MATHEMATICS II (Engineering) Solution (continued...) Hence ∂2 ∂t 2 U(p, t) = c 2(−p2U(p, t)). Letting D := ∂ ∂t , it follows that D 2U(p, t) + c 2p2U(p, t) = 0, i.e., (D 2 + c 2p2)U(p, t) = 0. From Calculus, we obtain U(p, t) = A(p) cos cpt + B(p) sin cpt (1) Note: The constants of integration must in general be functions of the second variable (in this case, p) since we have this variable ﬁxed for purposes of solving the equation. TSF - BOUNDARY VALUE PROBLEMS: FOURIER TRANSFORMS METHODSMATH2014 : MATHEMATICS II (Engineering) Solution (continued...) From the boundary condition (ii), we get ∂ ∂t U(p, 0) = 0. Diﬀerentiating (1) gives ∂U ∂t = −cpA(p) sin cpt + cpB(p) cos cpt. Setting t = 0, we get 0 = 0 + cpB(p) so that B(p) = 0, c ̸= 0, p ̸= 0. Hence U(p, t) = A(p) cos cpt so U(p, 0) = A(p). From (1), U(p, 0) = F[u(x, 0)] and so A(p) = 1 √2π ∫ ∞ −∞ u(x, 0)e −ixpdx = 1 √2π ∫ 1 −1(1 − |x|)e −ixpdx. TSF - BOUNDARY VALUE PROBLEMS: FOURIER TRANSFORMS METHODSMATH2014 : MATHEMATICS II (Engineering) Solution (continued...) Since 1 − |x|, and (1 − |x|)(cos xp) are even, (1 − |x|)(sin xp) is odd and e −ixp = cos xp − i sin xp, we get A(p) = 1 √ 2π ∫ 1 −1(1 − |x|)e−ixp dx = √ 2 π ∫ 1 0 (1 − x) cos xpdx − i √ 2π · 0 = √ 2 π [ (1 − x) sin xp p − (−1)(− cos xp) p2 ]1 0 = √ 2 π [ 0 − 0 − cos p p2 + 1 p2 ] = √ 2 π 1 − cos p p2 . Therefore, U(p, t) = √ 2 π 1−cos p p2 cos cpt. TSF - BOUNDARY VALUE PROBLEMS: FOURIER TRANSFORMS METHODSMATH2014 : MATHEMATICS II (Engineering) Solution (continued...) Taking inverse Fourier transforms, we get u(x, t) = 1 √ 2π ∫ ∞ −∞ U(p, t)e ixpdp = 1 √ 2π ∫ ∞ −∞ √ 2 π 1 − cos p p2 cos cpte ixpdp. Since 1−cos p p2 cos cpte ixp is even, we get u(x, t) = 2 π ∫ ∞ 0 1 − cos p p2 cos cpt cos xpdp. TSF - BOUNDARY VALUE PROBLEMS: FOURIER TRANSFORMS METHODSMATH2014 : MATHEMATICS II (Engineering) Question How are the sine and cosine transforms related to the usual Laplace transforms? Proposition Let f (t) be a real function. Then Fc[f (t)] − iFs[f (t)] = √ 2 π L[f (t)]s=iω so that Fc [f (t)] = √ 2 π Re {L[f (t)]s=iω } and Fs [f (t)] = − √ 2 π Im {L[f (t)]s=iω } . TSF - BOUNDARY VALUE PROBLEMS: FOURIER TRANSFORMS METHODSMATH2014 : MATHEMATICS II (Engineering) Example Let f (t) = e −t. Find Fs[f (t)]. Solution By the proposition, Fs[f (t)] = − √ 2 π Im {L[f (t)]s=iω} = − √ 2 π Im {∫ ∞ 0 e −stf (t)dt|s=iω } = − √ 2 π Im {∫ ∞ 0 e −iωt · e −tdt} = − √ 2 π Im {∫ ∞ 0 e −t(iω+1)dt} TSF - BOUNDARY VALUE PROBLEMS: FOURIER TRANSFORMS METHODSMATH2014 : MATHEMATICS II (Engineering) Solution (continued...) That is, Fs[f (t)] = − √ 2 π Im {−e −t(iω+1) 1 + iω | ∞ 0 } = − √ 2 π Im { 1 1 + iω } = − √ 2 π Im { 1 − iω 1 + ω2 } = √ 2 π · ω 1 + ω2 . TSF - BOUNDARY VALUE PROBLEMS: FOURIER TRANSFORMS METHODSMATH2014 : MATHEMATICS II (Engineering) Example By taking Fourier sine transforms with respect to x, solve the Laplace equation ∂2u ∂x 2 + ∂2u ∂y 2 = 0 in a semi-inﬁnite strip (0 < y < 1, x > 0) given that (i) u = 0 when y = 0, i.e., u(x, 0) = 0 (ii) u = e −x when y = 1, i.e., u(x, 1) = e −x (iii) u = y when x = 0, i.e., u(0, y ) = y . NB u −→ 0 as x −→ ∞. TSF - BOUNDARY VALUE PROBLEMS: FOURIER TRANSFORMS METHODSMATH2014 : MATHEMATICS II (Engineering) Solution We transform x to p and let Fs[u(x, y )] = Us(p, y ). Then from ∂2u ∂x 2 + ∂2u ∂y 2 = 0, we get Fs [∂2u ∂x 2 ] + Fs [ ∂2u ∂y 2 ] = 0 i.e., [−p2Us(p, y ) + √ 2 π pu(0, y )] + ∂2 ∂y 2 Us(p, y ) = 0. Hence denoting by D := ∂ ∂y , we get (D 2 − p2)Us(p, y ) = − √ 2 π pu(0, y ). TSF - BOUNDARY VALUE PROBLEMS: FOURIER TRANSFORMS METHODSMATH2014 : MATHEMATICS II (Engineering) Solution (continued...) By (iii), this gives (D 2 − p2)Us(p, y ) = −√ 2 π py . By methods in Calculus, Us(p, y ) = A(p)e −py + B(p)e py − 1 D 2 − p2 √ 2 π py . Now 1 D2 − p2 √ 2 π py = √ 2 π p · 1 −p2 1 (1 − D2 p2 ) · y = − √ 2 π 1 p (1 + D2 p2 + · · · )y = − √ 2 π y p . TSF - BOUNDARY VALUE PROBLEMS: FOURIER TRANSFORMS METHODSMATH2014 : MATHEMATICS II (Engineering) Solution (continued...) Therefore, Us(p, y ) = A(p)e −py + B(p)e py + √ 2 π y p . (2) From (i), Us(p, 0) = 0, so putting y = 0 in (2) gives 0 = A(p) + B(p), so that B(p) = −A(p). It follows that Us(p, y ) = A(p)e −py − A(p)e py + √ 2 π y p . (3) TSF - BOUNDARY VALUE PROBLEMS: FOURIER TRANSFORMS METHODSMATH2014 : MATHEMATICS II (Engineering) Solution (continued...) From (ii), Us(p, 1) = Fs[e −x ]. By the previous example, this is Us(p, 1) = Fs[e −x ] = √ 2 π p 1 + p2 . But from (3), Us(p, 1) = A(p)e −p − A(p)e p + √ 2 π 1 p . Therefore, A(p)[e −p − e p] + √ 2 π 1 p = √ 2 π p 1 + p2 . TSF - BOUNDARY VALUE PROBLEMS: FOURIER TRANSFORMS METHODSMATH2014 : MATHEMATICS II (Engineering) Solution (continued...) Therefore, A(p)[−2 sinh p] = √ 2 π { p 1 + p2 − 1 p } = √ 2 π −1 p(1 + p2) so that A(p) = √ 2 π 1 p(1 + p2)2 sinh p . TSF - BOUNDARY VALUE PROBLEMS: FOURIER TRANSFORMS METHODSMATH2014 : MATHEMATICS II (Engineering) Solution (continued...) Hence Us (p, y ) = A(p)[e−py − epy ] + √ 2 π y p = √ 2 π 1 p(1 + p2) sinh p · −1 2 (epy − e−py ) + √ 2 π y p = − √ 2 π sinh py p(1 + p2) sinh p + √ 2 π y p . TSF - BOUNDARY VALUE PROBLEMS: FOURIER TRANSFORMS METHODSMATH2014 : MATHEMATICS II (Engineering) Solution (continued...) Assuming that u(x, y ) is odd with respect to x and taking inverse sine transforms: u(x, y ) = √ 2 π ∫ ∞ 0 Us (p, y ) sin xpdp = √ 2 π ∫ ∞ 0 √ 2 π { − sinh py p(1 + p2) sinh p + y p } sin xpdp = 2 π ∫ ∞ 0 − sinh py p(1 + p2) sinh p sin xpdp + 2 π y ∫ ∞ 0 sin xp p dp. But ∫ ∞ 0 sin xp p dp = π 2 . Therefore, u(x, y ) = y − 2 π ∫ ∞ 0 sinh py p(1 + p2) sinh p sin xpdp. TSF - BOUNDARY VALUE PROBLEMS: FOURIER TRANSFORMS METHODSMATH2014 : MATHEMATICS II (Engineering)
